entry.et: Middle English dede, from Old English dǣd; akin to Old English dōn to do

def.dt: :a usually illustrious act or action :feat exploit a hero's daring deeds
:the act of performing :action righteous in word and in deed
:a signed and usually sealed instrument containing some legal transfer, bargain, or contract

entry.et: deed + poll, adjective, having the edges cut even rather than indented, from poll

def.dt: :a deed (as to change one's name) made and executed by only one party
:a legal instrument used to release one person's right, title, or interest to another without providing a guarantee or warranty of title
:the deed constituting the evidence of a person's legal ownership
:a deed warranting that the grantor has a good title free and clear of all liens and encumbrances and will defend the grantee against all claims
